repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Social Security Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, although institutional development
            impacts were only modest. Lessons reinforce the importance
            of project ownership, and of continuity within the
            implementation team, and further suggest the following.
            Promoting a culture of strategic planning for project
            management is essential, as is the need for better defined
            mechanisms for project monitoring and control. It is thus
            suggested that instruments for control of project activities
            be designed well before implementation begins, to be then
            fine-tuned during the period of execution, particularly for
            information technology (IT) systems. Other lessons reinforce
            the need to maintain flexibility, and also recommend
            maintaining contact with middle income countries, given, as
            in this case, Social Security system reforms in Brazil were
            the culmination of many years of economic and sector work
            (ESW) and policy dialogue; as such, this association played
            a valuable role, providing the Bank a deeper knowledge in
            this process

5086159.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social protection and risk management,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Social Security Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Security Technical Assistance
            Project, will support the design, and implementation of
            institutional, and legal reforms, needed for the second
            phase of the Social Security, and Pension Reform in Brazil,
            and, within the strategic context, it responds financially
            to such reforms. The components are: 1) restructuring of the
            National Institute for Social Security (INSS), which
            requires studies on diagnostic/strategic plans, and an
            information system master plan. Additionally, studies on a
            public information/dissemination strategy, and an evaluation
            of the Unified Data Base of Social Information (CNIS) will
            be implemented to enhance information, and institution
            building. The Management of Contributors by Segment (SGS)
            will be implemented, and, will include equipment supply; 2)
            pension and insurance legal frameworks, will be developed
            through studies emphasizing on regulation of work related
            injury insurance, and, the regulation for the Private Sector
            Workers Pension System (RGPS); 3) strengthening of the
            Secretariat of Complementary Pension Funds (SCP), which call
            for the preparation of complementary laws, and, design of
            investment, actuarial, financial, and supervision models, in
            addition to equipment supply. Further studies will focus on
            the preparation of Ordinary laws, strategic planning for
            regulatory agencies, and, expansion of the integrated
            information system, and external information network.
